John Arrowwood wrote:

>I've restarted the experiment with it being required to be successful at 
>enlargement before it does reduction.  It's proceeding much faster now!
>
>I also took a long hard look at how MUCH enlargement I was asking of it.  
>16x is too much to ask it to try to learn on.  So I made a minor 
>modification that lets me first train it to do  2x.  Once it appears to be 
>able to do 2x, I can up the expected amount of enlargement to 3x, 4x, 5x, 
>and so on, until I max out forward progress.  That should make things 
>progress much faster.  But we'll have to wait and see if theory meets 
>reality. :)
>  
>
Hi John,

I suppose if you take the logic that we applied to Chad's cross product 
problem then it would make more sense to test against a spread of 
enlargement/reduction factors on each evaluation. Otherwise you might 
see overfitting at the enlargement end of the scale similar to the 
signal averaging you observed with reduction.  I guess that would slow 
your experiment down quite a lot though huh :(

Colin
